Name: Adobe Commerce
Architecture: Hybrid platform, combining an open-code system with micro-SaaS solutions.
Recommended for: Shops running on an older version of Magento 2 needing an upgrade or those heavily utilizing Adobe's Experience Cloud Solutions.
Impact on customer's IT: Depending on the selected setup, developers may not be required.
Development approach: The shop is primarily built by configuring various Adobe products, including App Builder, domain services (e.g., search and payment), Adobe Experience Manager, and Experience Platform.
Storefront approach: New projects can start with a boilerplate template (demo, code) that  that utilizes the system’s GraphQL API.
Hosting description: Shops are individually hosted on Adobe Commerce Cloud, which runs on AWS or Azure.
Extendibility concept: Developers can extend the PHP code of the underlying Magento 2 instance, but not the embedded SaaS solutions, although this is often unnecessary.

Name: Commercetools
Recommended for: Enterprise shops with advanced but standard e-commerce needs. Commercetools is also especially suited for healthcare projects because of their HIPAA compliance.
Impact on customer's IT: You'll need engineers to maintain your storefront and integration services. If using their templates, ensure your team has JavaScript  experience (Next.js and Node).
Development approach: You'll need to implement both your storefront and integration services using either your preferred technologies or the provided templates.
Storefront approach:
Projects may start building from scratch or use their commercetools Frontend solution, which is an entire suite of tools, that consists of 

* a Next.js based storefront, including a set of React components, pre-integrated with Commercetools. There are templates for B2C and B2B scenarios.
* a hosting environment that is based on a Node.js environment (Extension runner) and a frontend delivery system (Frontend delivery) based on Netlify and GCP
* a visual site builder for non-technical users called Studio:

https://docs.commercetools.com/frontend-studio/static/7d011c7bfc67b7ec4dd6c012e19488a5/a4f81/site-builder-area.png
Hosting description: Commercetools is a multi-tenant SaaS fully managed by the vendor. Custom storefronts and integration services can be deployed via their Connect offering or any other hosting provider.
Success Stories: APG & Co,Audi,Bang & Olufsen,Bikes.de,BMW,Cargo Crew,Danone,Express,Just Eat Takeaway,Loomstate,Nieuwkoop Europe,Normet,Treedom,Vision Healthcare

Name: HCL Commerce
Recommended for: Large enterprises seeking a mature, Java-based system with full code access.
Impact on customer's IT: You’ll need a team of senior-level Java engineers to manage the HCL Commerce backend and frontend engineers to develop the storefront.
Development approach: Projects typically start with either the B2C or B2B template, then extend the source code as needed.
Storefront approach:
You can choose from several approaches to build your storefront:

1. The traditional MVC approach using JSPs, Struts, and Spring MVC, with a starter store called Aurora based on jQuery.

2. A modern approach using Next.js (Ruby).

3. A React-based approach with Emerald for B2C and Sapphire for B2B.

Alternatively, you can also build your custom storefront using the system’s GraphQL API.
Hosting description: Customers can operate their shop on-premise using provided Docker and Kubernetes artifacts or opt for the managed hosting service, HCL Now, which supports any cloud provider (e.g., AWS, GCP, or Azure). You can read more about HCL Now in their blog post.
Extendibility concept: Custom logic is developed directly in the system's source code. HCL Commerce provides a complete development suite based on J2EE, Spring, ElasticSearch (or Solr), and IBM DB2 (or Oracle DB).
More information:
History

HCL Commerce, formerly known as IBM WebSphere Commerce, is an e-commerce platform that was originally developed by IBM in the 1990s. In 2019, HCL Technologies acquired the platform from IBM as part of a broader software acquisition. 

The initial version, called NetCommerce, was developed to sell event tickets and merchandise for the 1996 Olympic Games (source).

Name: Lunar
Recommended for: Startups or small retailers seeking a basic solution based on Laravel.
Impact on customer's IT: You’ll need a team of engineers that a familiar with Laravel and PHP.
Development approach: Lunar is installed as a Composer package within any Laravel application. Starting with the Starter Kit, the code is then extended as needed.
Storefront approach: New projects can be launched with their Livewire Starter Kit. Livewire enables developers to implement interactive user interfaces using only PHP.
Hosting description: Shops based on Lunar can be self-hosted; typically using one of the official Laravel offerings, like Laravel Cloud, Vapor or Forge.
Extendibility concept: Lunar provides internal extension points that allow the injection of custom classes. For example, there is a configurable array of classes (“pipeline”) for cart calculation. Additionally, all models (Eloquent ORM) can be replaced.

Name: MedusaJS
Recommended for: Startups seeking a powerful, modern solution that can be self-hosted and don't require the support of an established vendor or additional security certifications.
Impact on customer's IT: You'll need an in-house IT team to manage and maintain your entire webshop.
Development approach: Since Medusa is open-source, you can clone the starter template and begin development with your team. Premium support is also available if needed.
Storefront approach: Medusa is a headless system, meaning you'll need to build your own storefront. However, it includes an optional template built with Next.js to help you get started. (demo).
Hosting description: You can deploy Medusa to any provider, with deployment recipes available for platforms like Heroku and DigitalOcean. The Medusa team is also working on "Medusa Cloud," a hosting solution currently in beta.
Extendibility concept: Developers have complete access to the entire Medusa codebase.
More information:
Versions

Currently, Medusa is available in version 1, with version 2 actively being developed.

→ https://medusajs.com/blog/toward-medusa-2/

Technologies & Architecture

Medusa 2.0 is a Node.js-based headless commerce platform with a modular architecture. It uses technologies like TypeORM, PostgreSQL, and follows concepts such as REST and event-driven architecture.

→ https://docs.medusajs.com/development/fundamentals/architecture-overview

Recipes

Medusa can be applied to various use cases, such as B2C, marketplaces, OMS, and POS. To simplify the setup, they offer ready-made recipes that automate the foundational configuration.

→ https://docs.medusajs.com/recipes/

Name: Salesforce B2C Commerce
Recommended for: Companies that are already invested into the Salesforce tool landscape, want to fully outsource their B2C shop to a SaaS platform.
Impact on customer's IT: You'll primarily need JavaScript developers for building the storefront and handling integrations using Cartridges.
Development approach: Projects typically start by customizing one of the demo shops, followed by developing custom integrations, which are injected into the SaaS platform.
Storefront approach:
Projects usually begin by customizing the Demo shop, which is built on the Storefront Reference Architecture (SFRA) using Server-Side JavaScript (SSJS) and ISML templates.

Alternatively, projects can be implemented with the more modern PWA Kit, which is based on React and also has a demo shop.

Lastly, teams may choose to build and host their own storefront using the system’s REST-APIs.
Hosting description: The Salesforce Commerce solution, as well as custom integrations (Cartridge) and the storefront are hosted within the Salesforce Commerce Cloud environment.
Extendibility concept: Integrations are implemented as "Cartridges," developed using JavaScript, specifically Server-Side JavaScript (SSJS) based on the Rhino engine (which translates JavaScript to Java on the server-side). A proprietary templating language “ISML” (Internet Store Markup Language) is used for rendering frontend templates. Each cartridge contains the logic, controllers, services, and templates. The system's source code is not accessible.
More information:
More information about Salesforce Commerce

As Salesforce Commerce is a pretty closed system, there is not much public information available. We recommend these posts:

* Oleg Sapishchuk explains Salesforce Commerce Cloud (SFCC), its architecture, integrations, and tools like Business Manager → https://osapishchuk.medium.com/how-to-understand-salesforce-commerce-cloud-78d71f1016de
* Thomas Theunen provides an overview of Salesforce Commerce Cloud and explains why it is not native to the Salesforce platform.  → https://www.salesforceben.com/salesforce-b2c-commerce-cloud-architecture-explained/

Alternative documentation

There is a community-driven alternative to the official documentation here: https://sfccdocs.com/

⚠️ B2C and B2B are different systems!

B2C Commerce 

Originally known as Demandware, an early cloud-based e-commerce solution, it was acquired by Salesforce in 2016. Salesforce B2C Commerce focuses on B2C commerce for retail brands. The platform can be extended using Salesforce Commerce Cloud’s proprietary scripting language, ISML (Internet Store Markup Language), along with JavaScript for front-end customizations. 

Salesforce B2B Commerce:

In contrast to the B2C system, the B2B Commerce solution is native to the Salesforce platform. As a result, it has a different architecture and requires different development skills, such as expertise in Apex, Lightning Web Components (LWC), and Salesforce’s declarative tools, compared to the JavaScript and ISML-based development used in B2C Commerce. You can read more about the differences here: https://www.salesforceben.com/salesforce-b2c-commerce-vs-b2b-commerce-what-are-the-differences/
Mobile App approach: The provided PWA Kit has a responsive design and can be utilized to build a mobile-friendly shop. There is no out-of-the-box template for a native app.

Name: SAP Commerce
Recommended for: Companies with established Java teams that are heavily invested in the SAP ecosystem.
Impact on customer's IT: You will need to maintain a larger in-house team of Java and JavaScript engineers.
Storefront approach: Storefronts are typically implemented using SAP's Composable Storefront (formerly known as Spartacus), an open-source template built on AngularJS (code)
Hosting description: The SAP Commerce Cloud is usally deployed on Azure or AWS and operated by SAP, with each customer receiving their own instance as it is not a multi-tenant SaaS application.
Extendibility concept: SAP Commerce is a modular application, based on Java and the Spring Framework.
Success Stories: Toyota Motor Philippines,DAIMANI,thyssenkrupp Materials Services,MVV Enamic,H&M
More information:

Name: Scayle
Recommended for: Large-scale B2C shops, ideally fashion or similar products.
Impact on customer's IT: You don’t need experienced engineers to extend the shop system since it’s a SaaS solution, but you will need a small team of engineers to maintain the storefront (Nuxt) and your integration middleware.
Development approach: A typical project involves implementing three systems: First, building a custom storefront, possibly using their template. Second, integrating Scayle with other systems by developing custom middleware. Third, potentially building a mobile app.
Storefront approach: Scayle is a headless SaaS platform, requiring you to build and operate your own storefront. They provide a Nuxt.js-based template (Storefront Boilerplate), but the checkout is rendered by Scayle and can only be configured.
Hosting description: While Scayle is a fully vendor-operated SaaS system, the customer is responsible for hosting their storefront and additional integration services.
Extendibility concept: Scayle can be extended through REST APIs and webhooks. The source code is not accessible to customers.
Success Stories: About You,Deichmann,Depot,Fielmann,Pierce Group,Tom Tailor,Witt Weiden,Manchester United
More information:
History

Scayle is a productized version of About You‘s self-developed shop system.
Mobile App approach: Since Scayle doesn’t provide a mobile boilerplate, you’ll need to build your own app using the REST APIs.

Name: Spryker
Architecture: Editable source code combined with managed hosting.
Recommended for: Complex use cases, such as B2B and marketplaces, which often require code-level changes to the core system to implement unique functionality.
Impact on customer's IT: To succeed with Spryker, having an experienced PHP development team is essential, ideally in-house.
Development approach: Projects typically start with the provided B2C or B2B template, followed by code customization and extension.
Storefront approach: Spryker offers traditional PHP-based demo shops for B2C and B2B scenarios. Alternatively, customers can use their modern web components approach, Oryx, or decide to their own storefront using Spryker’s REST API.
Hosting description: Projects are fully hosted and supported by Spryker PaaS+ on AWS.
Extendibility concept:
Customers extend Spryker on code-level (PHP). Any UI, business logic and database schema can be customized. Custom logic is typically developed as modules within the project's source code, resulting in a single modular application that extends Spryker’s core.

The source-code can be viewed and extended, see https://github.com/spryker/
More information:
Trivia

* Spryker is a modular application with over 1,000 modules, loaded into the project via Packagist → https://packagist.org/?query=spryker
* One of Spryker's strengths is its emphasis on Clean Code principles, improving the developer experience. This is reflected in its high score on the code analysis platform Scrutinizer → https://scrutinizer-ci.com/g/spryker/spryker-core/?branch=master
